captions.text:
So, after I did Avowed not too long 
back, it was pointed out that ages ago,

I reviewed a game called Unavowed. And now, all 
I need is to review a game called Disavowed,

and I&#39;ve covered the entire spectrum of avowing 
or profession progression. Hang on a sec;

hasty Steam search. Oh, what do you know? Well, I 
ain&#39;t reviewing that; looks like crap. Point is,

I didn&#39;t think Unavowed was half bad, 
and now the developer, Wadjet Eye Games,

has a new one out to continue spreading the good 
word of traditional point-and-click puzzling,

faintly stereotypical depictions of New York 
City, the viability of Adventure Game Studio

as a commercial dev platform, and remarkably 
good shoulder posture. In an alternative-future

New York, where modern technology has all but 
wiped out scoliosis, time travel exists and is

strictly controlled by the authorities. But in an 
interesting contrast to how this usually works,

the authorities aren&#39;t particularly hard-line 
about not changing history. They kinda treat

it like marijuana. Yes, we legalized it &#39;cause 
we know you fuckers are gonna use it anyway,

and this way, we can regulate it, but that doesn&#39;t 
mean you get to take the piss. You still can&#39;t

drive down the high street distributing 
blunts to the crowd with a snow shovel.

So, future corporation ChronoZen might sound like 
a doomed tech startup that sells digital watches

that don&#39;t work unless you download an app, but 
it&#39;s actually a time travel company that charges

rich clients through the nose to take holidays in 
the past and even lets them apply to make changes

to history that are assessed on a case-by-case 
basis, kind of like the way the American

government treats human rights violations. But you 
can&#39;t let the genetically engineered descendants

of Mark Zuckerberg run around history willy 
nilly, and that&#39;s where our protagonist comes

in. Fia Quinn, agent of ChronoZen, whose job is 
to escort wealthy clients to the past, keep them

and history safe, and come down like a ton of 
bricks on anyone trying to get in some sneaky

grandmother porking. The game spans multiple 
chapters covering multiple jobs to a variety

of temporal versions of New York City, including 
the present, the near future, the 19th century,

the Roaring Twenties, and the period just before 
and just after 9/11. Which is the point where we

all tug our collars and make a noise like Jerry 
Lewis trying to walk a tightrope. Nyeeeeeeeeeeh.

Will a day ever come when a time travel story can 
feature the 9/11 attacks without coming across a

bit nyeeeeeh? Probably not in my lifetime; I mean, 
I still remember them. I was a teenager. I very

clearly recall seeing those towers come down and 
being almost unable to finish that day&#39;s second

wank. But the time travel adventures give way 
over time to a compelling character story about

Fia herself who, along with the rest of ChronoZen 
having been time locked to prevent being erased by

history changes, has to deal with getting through 
daily life when everyone she knows, every book

she reads, and every artisanal backstreet coffee 
shop she frequents might get erased and replaced

with a Petco by the end of tomorrow&#39;s shift. 
I think Wadjet Eye Games have strong writing,

but I also feel their characters tend 
to have an interchangeable quality,

which might be partly explained by them all 
looking the fucking same. It&#39;s painfully

obvious that every character in Old Skies 
was made with the same animation template,

&#39;cause they&#39;ve all got the exact same 
stance. Shoulders back, hips cocked,

feet apart. Every now and again, they do some 
kind of bespoke action or gesture, and then

they snap right back to the jeans model pose 
before you notice how dodgy the tweening looks.

Everyone&#39;s got the same walk, too—a sort of 
determined, casual saunter that looks like

they&#39;ve just put the baby down at 3:00 in the 
morning and are praying to Teddy Bear Jesus

that they&#39;ll be able to leave the room before 
the little fucker starts crying again. Very

smoothly animated, but it makes me think 
of games like Chrono Trigger, with pixels

like a square foot of a mosaic bathroom floor and 
fewer frames than a burnt-down art supplies shop,

but every character has life and personality 
because of the unique way they move,

and it&#39;s a million times more visually pleasing 
than every character using a hundred million

frames to mosey across flat backdrops in 
perfect unison. There were moments when I

couldn&#39;t tell if character A looked exactly 
like a young version of character B because

the game was setting up a time travel-related 
twist or if the artist had just cheaped out,

recolored a preexisting hairdo, and was hoping I 
wouldn&#39;t notice. My other issue is puzzle design.

At any given moment in Old Skies, you are always 
on a perfectly straight line to the next solution;

you&#39;ll be lucky if there&#39;s more than one or two 
rooms you can access, and any attempt to interact

with anything but the intended solution 
will result in a verbal spit in the eye.

&quot;I don&#39;t need to worry about that.&quot; &quot;I don&#39;t 
need to go there.&quot; &quot;I&#39;m done with that thing.&quot;

How do you know you&#39;re done with that thing, 
Fia Quinn? I dunno, maybe the upturned bucket

we used to get the cat down from the potting 
shed might work equally well to knock out the

curious policeman or function as an amusing hat. 
I mean, god forbid I might be curious and want

to explore this historical setting I&#39;m on an 
amazing time travel adventure in. God forbid

I might want to talk to someone about something 
other than whatever petty step in the puzzle

sequence I&#39;m currently laser fixated on. Maybe I 
wanna go to the window washers on September 10th,

2001 and tell them they can probably phone it in 
a bit today. I suppose it does mean we never get

entrenched in any of that legendary adventure 
game moon logic for very long, but the laser

focus of proceedings can lead to things feeling 
very contrived. For example, we find ourselves

at one point needing to stop an assassination 
20 years in the future and—as luck would have

it—happen to be in a room containing nothing 
but the very shoes the assassin will be wearing

in 20 years and a prototype voice-activated 
explosive with precisely a 20-year shelf life.

Other moments feel contrived in other ways. Like 
the instance where we get cold bloodedly shot

by an angry cop unless we choose the exact right 
conversation options that will convince said cop

that gunning down unarmed white women is bad, 
actually and might be frowned upon by society.

But in the end, I was engaged by the story of 
Old Skies and was quite affected by the ending.

The game effectively pulls us out of Fia&#39;s head 
as time goes on as she starts making decisions

independent of our control in a way that sort 
of mirrors her growing dissatisfaction with

the rules that govern her existence, and in 
the end, she triumphs by breaking free of her

protagonist obligations; it&#39;s very apt. All 
wacky future time travel contrivances aside,

the plot at heart is about the frustrations of 
being stuck in one place while everything changes

around you. And that&#39;s pretty relatable. Also 
pretty analogous to the state of point-and-click

adventure games as a genre, now that I&#39;m 
writing it down. Ooh, now there&#39;s an idea.

A time travel adventure game where the entire 
adventure game genre tries to change its fate

by traveling back in time to the early 1970s and 
strangling John Carmack to death in the crib.
